questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding treatments for Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is correct?

choices.text: Early Start Denver Model (ESDM) primarily focuses on role-play activity for children with ASD.
Social Skills Training involves only individual therapy sessions where children practice social skills face-to-face with a therapist.
Treatment and Education of Autistic and Communication-Related Handicapped Children (TEACCH) employs structured teaching methods to support learning in children with ASD.
Pivotal Response Training emphasizes the use of pharmacological interventions to enhance communication skills in children with ASD.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Treatment and Education of Autistic and Communication-Related Handicapped Children (TEACCH) employs structured teaching methods to support learning in children with ASD.

Explanation:

TEACCH uses structured teaching methods, including visual aids, to facilitate learning and social interactions.

 

ASD Treatment:

  • Improve social interaction skills.
  • Enhance communication abilities.
  • Develop strategies for successful school integration.
  • Foster meaningful peer relationships.
  • Increase long-term independence in daily living.

Non-Pharmacological Treatment of Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD):

 

Psychosocial Interventions:

 

A) Early Intensive Behavioural and Developmental Interventions:

 

Model

Description

UCLA/LOVAAS-Based Model

Uses applied behaviour analysis (ABA) through one-on-one sessions focusing on specific skills.

Early Start Denver Model (ESDM)

Emphasises intervention in natural settings, involving parents and educators in daily routines (Option A).

Parent Training Approaches

Pivotal Response Training: Teaches parents to facilitate social and communication skills through daily activities (Option D).

 

B) Social Skills Approaches: Includes social skills training. Therapists lead group sessions to practise social skills and emotion identification (Option B).

C) Behavioural Interventions (BIs) and Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT):

  • Behavioural Therapy: Effective in reducing repetitive behaviours; often combined with medication.
  • Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT): Helpful for anxiety, depression and OCD.

D) Educational Interventions:

 

  • TEACCH (Treatment and Education of Autistic and Communication-Related Handicapped Children) involves structured teaching methods using visual aids and controlled environments to promote learning and enhance social skills (Option C).

 

  • Broad-Based Approaches: Combine various teaching methods, incorporating behavioural analysis and language remediation.


Computer-Based and Virtual Reality Approaches: Computer programs are used to teach language and reading skills, such as the “Let's Face It!” program.

questions.text: A 10 year old girl is brought to the clinic with concerns about her frequent eye-blinking, shoulder-shrugging and vocalizations that started at age 5. Her symptoms have worsened over the past year, leading to social difficulties and bullying at school. What is the most appropriate initial treatment approach for this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Psychoeducation for Family and School
 

Explanation:

The child is likely experiencing Tourette Syndrome, characterised by the presence of both motor (eye-blinking, shoulder-shrugging) and vocal tics that began before age 18. Psychoeducation is an appropriate initial treatment approach as it helps the family and school understand the condition, reducing stress and misinterpretations, which can improve the child's social interactions.

Tourette Syndrome

  • Definition: Neuropsychiatric disorder characterized by motor and vocal tics, usually emerging in childhood.
  • Onset & Course:
    • Age: Tics begin between 4-6 years, and peak at 10-12 years.
    • Waxing and waning tics, with possible remission periods.
  • Pathophysiology: Basal ganglia dysfunction, particularly dopaminergic transmission in cortico-striatothalamic circuits.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Both motor and vocal tics for over 1 year, onset before 18.
    • Motor tics typically start in the face & neck, and progress downward.
  • Indications for Treatment: Severe tics causing social or emotional issues, physical discomfort, or academic problems.

Treatment

Psychoeducation

Educating families and schools to reduce stress and avoid misinterpretation of tics.

Behavioural Therapy
  • Habit Reversal Training (HRT): Most effective and currently the first-line behavioural treatment for tic disorders
  • Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP): Prolonged tic suppression.

Pharmacotherapy
  • Atypical Antipsychotics: Risperidone (most studied), Aripiprazole (fewer side effects).
  • Typical Antipsychotics: Haloperidol, Pimozide (higher risk of side effects).
  • Noradrenergic Agents: Clonidine, Guanfacine (modest efficacy, useful with ADHD).
  • Other: Tetrabenazine, Topiramate, THC (understudy)

Supportive Approaches

Relaxation training, biofeedback, SSRIs for OCD.

 

Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) (Option A): While CBT can be helpful, the initial approach should focus on education to manage misconceptions about tics.

Typical Antipsychotics like Haloperidol (Option C): These are generally reserved for cases where tics cause significant distress, making them a secondary option after psychoeducation.

Noradrenergic Agents like Clonidine (Option D): These agents can be considered later, especially if there is comorbid ADHD, but they are not the first line in this scenario.

questions.text: A 9 year old girl has repetitive shoulder-shrugging and grunting sounds that occur daily. These actions are involuntary but she can suppress them for short periods. Which of the following best describes her tics?

choices.text: Simple Motor and Simple Vocal Tics
Complex Motor and Simple Vocal Tics
Simple Motor and Complex Vocal Tics
Complex Motor and Complex Vocal Tics

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Simple Motor and Simple Vocal Tics

 

Explanation:

Shoulder-shrugging (simple motor) and grunting (simple vocal) are both rapid, brief, and uncomplicated tics.

Tic Disorders and Types of Tics

  • Definition: Tic disorders are neuropsychiatric conditions marked by brief, rapid involuntary motor movements or vocalizations, often triggered by irresistible urges.
  • Pathophysiology: Involves dysfunction in the basal ganglia and disrupted dopaminergic transmission within the cortico-striatothalamic circuits.
  • Age of Onset: Tics typically emerge between ages 5-6, peaking in severity from ages 10-12.
  • Course: Tics may be transient or chronic, exhibiting a waxing and waning pattern.

Types of Tics:

Motor Tics

Involuntary movements
  • Simple Motor Tics

Rapid contractions of specific muscle groups (e.g., eye-blinking, head-jerking, shoulder-shrugging).
  • Complex Motor Tics (Options B and D)

More purposeful movements (e.g., grooming behaviours, jumping, touching objects).

Vocal Tics

Involuntary Vocalizations
  • Simple Vocal Tics

Basic sounds (e.g., throat-clearing, grunting, sniffing), echopraxia (imitation of observed behaviour), and copropraxia (display of obscene gestures).
  • Complex Vocal Tics (Option C)

Elaborate phrases or behaviours (e.g., coprolalia - involuntary use of obscene words; palilalia - repeating one’s own words; echolalia - repeating the last heard words from others).

questions.text: A 9 year old boy has frequent temper outbursts at home and school that are out of proportion to the situation, occurring at least three times per week. Between outbursts, he is persistently irritable and has difficulty maintaining friendships. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder
 

Explanation:

The scenario presents frequent severe outbursts with chronic irritability between episodes, a hallmark of Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder
 

Disorder

Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder (DMDD)

Definition
  • Severe, developmentally inappropriate temper outbursts with a persistently irritable or angry mood.
  • Chronic disorder, with a high risk of progression to major depressive disorder, dysthymia, and anxiety.

Diagnostic Criteria (DSM-5)
  • Duration: ≥12 months, with no symptom-free period exceeding 3 months.
  • Outbursts: Occur ≥3 times/week, verbal or physical, out of proportion to the situation.
  • Age: Symptoms start before age 10 but diagnosis is not made before age 6 or after 18.
  • Mood Between Outbursts: Persistently irritable/angry, observable by others.
  • Settings: Symptoms present in at least two settings (home, and school).

Epidemiology
  • More common in males (78%) than females (22%).
  • Mean age of onset: 5 to 11 years.

Clinical Features
  • Verbal or physical aggression towards people or property.
  • They have persistently irritable moods between outbursts.
  • Impacts social relationships and school performance.

Treatment
  • Pharmacologic: SSRIs and stimulants (if pathophysiology resembles unipolar depression or anxiety). Atypical antipsychotics and mood stabilizers (if resemble bipolar disorder).
  • Psychosocial Interventions: Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), behavioural psychotherapy.

 

Oppositional Defiant Disorder (Option A): ODD involves defiance and irritability but lacks the explosive temper outbursts characteristic of DMDD.

 

Conduct Disorder (Option B): Conduct disorder involves aggression and violation of others' rights, which are not mentioned in this case.

 

Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (Option D): ADHD is characterised by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity, but not the frequent, severe outbursts seen in DMDD.

questions.text: A 9 year old boy frequently argues with his parents and teachers, often refuses to follow rules, and deliberately annoys his classmates. He seems angry most of the time but has no history of physical aggression or breaking the law. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Oppositional Defiant Disorder

 

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of frequent arguments, refusal to follow rules, and deliberate annoyance, without severe aggression or rule violations, point to a diagnosis of Oppositional defiant disorder.

 

Disorder

Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD)

Conduct Disorder

Definition

The persistent pattern of negativistic, defiant, disobedient, and hostile behaviour toward authority figures.

A persistent pattern of behaviour involving aggression, violating others' rights, and disregarding social norms.

Diagnostic Criteria (DSM-5)
  • Duration: ≥6 months.
  • Symptoms (≥4):
  • Losing temper.
  • Easily annoyed/sensitive.
  • Angry/resentful.
  • Argues with authority figures.
  • Refuses requests/rules.
  • Deliberately annoys others.
  • Blames others for their own mistakes/behaviors.
  • Spiteful/vindictive (at least 2x in 6 months).
  • No severely aggressive or delinquent behaviours.
  • Duration: ≥12 months, with 1 symptom present in the last 6 months.
  • Symptoms (≥3):
  • Physical aggression or threats.
  • Destruction of property.
  • Deceitfulness or theft.
  • Harming animals.
  • Violation of rules (e.g., truancy, running away).

Types (DSM-5)
  • Angry/Irritable Mood: Frequent temper loss, persistent irritability.
  • Argumentative/Defiant Behavior: Argues, refuses to comply, blames others.
  • Vindictiveness: Spiteful/vindictive actions ≥2x in 6 months.
  • Childhood-onset: Symptoms before age 10.
  • Adolescent-Onset: Symptoms after age 10.
  • Unspecified-Onset: Age of onset unknown

Severity Specifiers
  • Mild: Symptoms in 1 setting.
  • Moderate: Symptoms in 2 settings.
  • Severe: Symptoms in ≥3 settings.
  • Mild: Few conduct problems, minor harm.
  • Moderate: Intermediate symptoms.
  • Severe: Many symptoms, significant harm caused.

Treatment
  • Family Interventions: Parent training in child management, reinforcing positive behaviour.
  • Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): Parents are taught to discourage the child's oppositional behaviour by not paying much attention to it.
  • Parenting Techniques: Focus on reducing harsh punishment, and increasing positive interactions.
  • Psychosocial Interventions: Early intervention, CBT, school-based programs.
  • Pharmacologic Interventions: Antipsychotics (risperidone, quetiapine), SSRIs for impulsivity/irritability, sodium valproate.

Conduct Disorder (Option A): Does not fit, as there is no evidence of severe aggression or serious rule-breaking behaviour.

 

Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (Option C): No signs of inattention or hyperactivity are mentioned, which are key in ADHD.

 

Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder (DMDD) (Option D): Lacks the severe, recurrent temper outbursts and mood dysregulation typical of DMDD.

questions.text: A multidisciplinary team is reviewing treatment protocols for a 10 year old child diagnosed with intellectual disability. Which of the following does NOT form part of the treatment protocols for mental retardation?

choices.text: Screening for PKU and dietary management
Public education on avoiding alcohol during pregnancy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Risperidone to enhance cognitive functioning

 

Explanation:

There are no specific medications proven to enhance cognitive functioning in individuals with intellectual disabilities, making this option not part of standard treatment protocols. However, symptomatic treatment for associated features can be given like Risperidone (Antipsychotic) for rage, aggression, and self-injurious behaviours and SSRIs for depression.

 

Aetiology of Mental retardation:

Treatment:

1. Prevention

  • Primary Prevention involves actions to eliminate or reduce conditions that lead to intellectual disability, such as screening for PKU and providing a low phenylalanine diet (Option A).
    • Public education on avoiding alcohol during pregnancy (Option B).
    • Improving public health policies.
    • Genetic counselling for families with a history of genetic disorders.
  • Secondary Prevention focuses on promptly addressing medical and psychiatric complications to diminish their impact on individuals with intellectual disabilities.
  • Tertiary Prevention aims to minimise the long-term consequences of intellectual disabilities through effective early treatments for hereditary disorders like PKU and hypothyroidism, using dietary control or hormone replacement therapy.

  

2. Pharmacotherapy

  • For symptomatic treatment.
  • Antipsychotics like aripiprazole and risperidone for aggression, rage, irritability, and self-injurious behaviour.
  • Depression- Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs).

 

3. Psychosocial Interventions

  • Educational Interventions:
    • Comprehensive programs for academics, adaptive, social, and vocational skills.
    • Focus on communication and quality of life.
  • Behavioural and Cognitive-Behavioral Interventions:
    • Use of behaviour therapy and positive reinforcement.
    • Cognitive therapy for false beliefs and relaxation.
    • Psychodynamic therapy for family conflicts and anxiety.
  • Family Education (Option D):
    • Educate families on enhancing competence and managing expectations.
    • Provide ongoing counselling and support.
    • Share current medical information and resources.
  • Social Intervention:
    • Improve social skills and reduce isolation.
    • Programs like the Special Olympics enhance fitness, friendships, and self-esteem.

questions.text: A 12 year old boy is brought to a clinic for evaluation. His parents report that he has attended school only up to 2nd class and struggles with basic tasks such as dressing and feeding himself. The child is often unable to communicate effectively and requires constant supervision. He has an IQ of 40 and a mental age of approximately 5 years. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Moderate mental retardation

 

Explanation:

The child has an IQ of 40, which falls within the range of 35-49, indicating moderate mental retardation. He can be trained for semi-skilled or unskilled work but requires significant support.

 

Classification of mental retardation

Mild mental retardation
  • Most common in nearly 85% of cases
  • IQ of 50-69 (Option A)
  • Can study up to 6th class.
  • Educable
  • Maximum mental age that can be achieved - 12 years
  • Can achieve self-sufficiency

Moderate mental retardation
  • IQ of 35-49
  • Can study up to 2nd class
  • Trainable
  • Maximum mental age that can be achieved - 9 years
  • Can be trained for semi-skilled or unskilled work

Severe mental

retardation
  • IQ of 20-34 (Option C)
  • No formal education
  • Dependent
  • Maximum mental age that can be achieved - 6 years
  • Can perform simple tasks under close supervision

Profound mental

retardation
  • Least common - 1-2% of cases.
  • IQ < 20 (Option D)
  • No formal education
  • Need support in basic things such as eating, and using the washroom
  • Maximum mental age that can be achieved - 3 years
  • Need continuous supervision

questions.text: A 15 year old boy has been assessed for cognitive abilities, and his mental age is determined to be 9 years. What is the IQ based on the provided information?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 60

 

Explanation:

The child’s IQ calculated using the formula is 60, indicating significant limitations in intellectual functioning.

  1. Using the IQ formula:
    IQ=(Mental Age/Chronological Age)×100
  2. Substituting the ages:
    • Mental Age: 9 years
    • Chronological Age: 15 years
  3. IQ = (9/15)×100 = 60 (Options B, C, and D)

 

Intellectual Disability

  • Significant limitations in both:
    • Intellectual functioning –reasoning, learning, problem-solving.
    • Adaptive behaviour – conceptual, social, and practical skills.
  • Onset before 18 years.

 

Intelligence quotient

  • Intelligence is usually measured by calculating IQ.
  • IQ is an intelligence quotient.
  • IQ = (Mental age ÷ Chronological age) x 100
    • Chronological age - Age calculated from the date of birth.
    • Mental age - The age of one's intellect.
    • Various tests are done to calculate mental age.
  • Normal IQ: 90-109
  • Borderline IQ: 80-89
  • Mental retardation: IQ < 70

questions.text: A 10 year old girl has always loved school but is now struggling academically. Her teacher notes that she confuses similar-looking letters when reading and has trouble decoding words. She often asks for help with reading and feels frustrated with writing tasks. Her writing is messy and often lacks punctuation. Although she can do basic math, she struggles to remember mathematical signs and makes careless calculation errors. Which specific learning disorder is she most likely experiencing?

choices.text: Specific learning disorder with impairment in reading
Specific learning disorder with impairment in written expression
Specific learning disorder with impairment in mathematics

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Mixed disorder of scholastic skills

 

Explanation:

The child exhibits impairments in reading (difficulty decoding words), written expression (messy writing, omitted punctuation), and mathematics (difficulty with signs and calculations). The combination of these challenges indicates a mixed disorder of scholastic skills.

 

Specific Learning Disorders

 

  • Neurodevelopmental disorder beginning in early childhood
  • Both heritable and environmental factors like lead poisoning, Fetal Alcohol Syndrome, and in-utero drug exposure are responsible.
  • Persistent difficulty in learning academic skills such as reading, written expression or mathematics.
  • Inconsistent with the intellectual ability of the child.
  • The IQ range is usually normal.

 

Types of Specific Learning Disorders

Specific learning disorder with impairment in reading (Dyslexia)
  • Identified in children aged 7-9 years.
  • Difficulty in recognizing words and sounding out words.
  • Slow, inaccurate reading.
  • Poor comprehension.
  • Difficulties with spelling.

Specific learning disorder with impairment in written expression (Specific Spelling Disorder/ Dysgraphia)
  • Poor writing skills.
  • Poor spelling.
  • Errors in grammar and punctuation.
  • Poor handwriting.

Specific learning disorder with impairment in mathematics (dyscalculia)
  • Identified in children aged 6-10 years.
  • Difficulty learning numerical.
  • Difficulty remembering signs such as +/ –.
  • Slow, inaccurate calculations.
  • Poor linguistic, perceptual, mathematical, and attention skills.

Mixed disorder of scholastic skills

Combined impairment of reading, written expressions, and mathematics.

 

Specific learning disorder with impairment in reading (Option A), Specific learning disorder with impairment in written expression (Option B), and Specific learning disorder with impairment in mathematics (Option C) each focus on individual disabilities associated with reading, writing, and math, respectively, while this child exhibits difficulties across all three areas.

questions.text: A 7 year old boy diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder presents with significant irritability, including frequent temper tantrums and aggressive behaviours towards others. His parents report that these behaviours have led to difficulties at home and school. Which of the following pharmacological treatments would be most appropriate for this child's irritability?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Risperidone

 

Explanation:

Risperidone is FDA-approved for treating irritability in children with ASD and is commonly prescribed for this purpose.

 

Psychopharmacological Interventions of Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD):

 

1. Medications for Irritability:

 

Medication

Description

Risperidone
  • FDA-approved
  • Blocks dopamine and serotonin receptors
  • Side effects: Weight gain, sleepiness.

Aripiprazole
  • FDA-approved
  • It is a serotonin and dopamine antagonist (5HT2A and D2), but a partial D2 agonist also.
  • Effective for tantrums and aggression
  • Side effects: Sedation and dizziness.

Olanzapine
  • Reduces irritability but is associated with significant weight gain.

 

2. Medications for Hyperactivity, Impulsivity, and Inattention:

 

Medication

Description

Methylphenidate (Ritalin)

Stimulant for ADHD and ASD; may increase irritability. (Option A)

Atomoxetine (Strattera)

Non-stimulants are effective for hyperactivity and inattention; side effects include sedation.

 

3. Medications for Repetitive and Stereotypic Behaviour:

 

Medication

Description

Antidepressants and Mood Stabilisers

Fluoxetine and risperidone may be used in managing repetitive behaviours. (Option D)

Quetiapine, Clozapine, Ziprasidone

Used for aggression and self-injury; requires monitoring due to side effects.

Lithium

Used clinically for treating aggressive or self-injurious behaviours when antipsychotic medications are ineffective.

 

Clonidine (Option C) may help with hyperactivity but is not specifically a first-line treatment for irritability in children with ASD.

questions.text: A 6 year old boy is brought to the clinic due to concerns about his inability to stay seated during class. His teacher notes that he often runs around the classroom during lessons, disrupting other students by talking out of turn and blurting out answers. At home, his parents observe that he struggles to wait for his turn when playing games and talks excessively. He does not show signs of forgetfulness or distractibility. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) ADHD - Predominantly Hyperactive/Impulsive Presentation

 

Explanation:

The child shows significant hyperactivity and impulsivity, such as difficulty sitting still and talking out of turn, with no signs of inattention.

Subtypes of ADHD

Combined Presentation

(Option A)

Predominantly Inattentive Presentation

(Option C)

Predominantly Hyperactive/Impulsive Presentation

(Option B)

6 or more symptoms of both inattention and Hyperactivity-Impulsivity
  • 6 or more symptoms of Inattention
  • <6 symptoms of Hyperactivity-Impulsivity
  • 6 or more symptoms of Hyperactivity/Impulsive subtype
  • <6 symptoms of Inattention

 

Clinical Features of ADHD

Hyperactivity

Attention Deficit

Impulsivity

Other
  • Restlessness
  • Difficulty remaining seated
  • Inappropriate running and climbing
  • Excessive talking
  • Interrupting others
  • Short attention span
  • Distractibility
  • Difficulty following instructions
  • Forgetfulness
  • Disorganisation
  • Procrastination
  • Acting without thinking
  • Difficulty waiting for their turn
  • Interrupting others
  • Blurting out answers
  • Emotional lability
  • Explosiveness
  • Irritability
  • Memory and thinking defects
  • Specific learning difficulties
  • Speech and Hearing deficits

Conduct Disorder (Option D): Conduct Disorder is associated with aggressive behaviour and rule violations, which are not observed here.

questions.text: A 4 year old boy is brought to the clinic because his parents have noticed a significant regression in his abilities over the past year. He previously spoke in full sentences, engaged in social play, and was potty trained but has now lost these skills. He exhibits behaviours resembling those seen in autism. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Heller's Syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • Heller's Syndrome is characterised by marked regression in multiple areas of development after at least two years of normal development, typically between the ages of 3 and 4.

 

Heller's Syndrome: Also known as childhood disintegrative disorder or disintegrative psychosis classified under Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) in DSM-5.

 

Characteristics:

  • Marked regression in multiple developmental areas after at least two years of normal development.
  • It typically occurs between 3 and 4 years of age.

Affected Developmental Domains:

Domain

Description

Language skills

Significant loss of previously acquired language abilities

Social responsiveness

Deterioration in social interactions

Play

Loss of interest or ability to engage in play

Motor skills

Regression in gross and fine motor skills

Bladder and bowel control

Loss of previously established control
  • After regression, children closely resemble those with autistic disorder.

Asperger's Syndrome:

  • No longer a separate diagnosis in DSM-5; now classified under ASD.
  • Characterised by:
    • Impaired social relatedness.
    • Repetitive and stereotyped behaviours.
    • No significant language delays or abnormalities.
    • Cognitive development is normal.

Asperger's Syndrome (Option A) does not typically involve regression of skills, as it is a form of autism without significant delays in language or cognitive development.

Tourette Syndrome (Option C): This condition involves the presence of motor and vocal tics and does not involve regression of previously acquired developmental skills.

Rett syndrome (Option D) primarily affects girls and usually presents with stereotypical hand-wringing and loss of motor function, not seen in this case.

questions.text: A 2 year old girl is brought to the paediatrician due to concerns about her development. Initially, she was meeting her developmental milestones but has started to lose skills such as spoken language and purposeful hand movements. O/E, she demonstrates facial grimacing and stereotypical hand-wringing movements. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rett Syndrome

 

Explanation:

Rett Syndrome is characterised by normal early development followed by a regression in skills, particularly communication and motor skills, along with stereotypic hand movements.

 

Rett Syndrome:

  • Rett Syndrome is now classified as a form of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) in the DSM-5.
  • A degenerative condition caused by a dominant X-linked gene (hence seen in females>males) due to mutations in the MECP2 gene.

Developmental Progression (Option B):

  • Initial development appears normal in infants till around 6 months of age.
  • After that, there is a loss of acquired skills (e.g., purposeful hand movements, spoken language) often replaced by unusual behaviours (e.g., stereotypical hand-wringing).

Symptoms of Rett Syndrome:

 

  • Ataxia
  • Facial grimacing & Teeth grinding
  • Deterioration of verbal communication
  • Breathing Issues: eg. hyperventilation, apnea, and breath-holding
  • Stereotypical Hand Movements: Eg. hand-wringing and hand-washing behaviours.
  • Gait disturbance leading to the development of scoliosis
  • Seizures (in 75% of the cases)
  • Muscle tone abnormalities: Evolution from hypotonia to spasticity and rigidity
  • Cerebral atrophy

Management

  • Trofinitide is a tripeptide approved by the FDA for Rett syndrome.

 

Long-term Prognosis - Generally poor prognosis:

  • May live up to 10 years post-symptom onset.
  • The developmental level typically stalls at that of a child under one-year-old.
  • Usually whee-chair bound.

Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) (Option A): While Rett Syndrome is now classified under ASD, it specifically involves a distinct pattern of regression and additional symptoms not typical of ASD alone.

Cerebral Palsy (Option C): This condition primarily involves motor impairment without the specific regression and stereotypical movements seen in Rett Syndrome.

Global Developmental Delay (Option D) refers to delays across multiple developmental domains but doesn't typically include the loss of previously acquired skills.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a common behavioural symptom associated with Autism Spectrum Disorder?

choices.text: Early development of a social smile

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Early development of a social smile

 

Explanation:

Children with ASD often lack a social smile during infancy, which indicates deficits in social communication.

 

Physical Symptoms of Autism:

 

  • Higher rates of minor physical anomalies (e.g., ear malformations).
  • Delayed or lack of handedness and lateralization (prolonged ambidexterity).
  • Abnormal dermatoglyphics (unusual fingerprint patterns).
  • Macrocephaly in >20% of patients (large head size develops by 5 years of age).

Behavioural Symptoms of Autism:

 

Symptom Category

Examples

Social Communication and Interaction Deficits

  • Lack of social smile, poor eye contact (Option B)
  • Atypical attachment behaviour
  • Difficulty with non-verbal communication
  • Challenges in forming and maintaining relationships
  • Awkward or inappropriate social behaviour

Restricted and Repetitive Behaviour Patterns

  • Limited exploratory play
  • Repetitive toy use (Option A)
  • Rigid, monotonous activities
  • Strong attachment to objects (Option D)
  • Self-stimulatory or self-injurious behaviours

Language Development Disturbances

  • Delays in language development (Option C)
  • Minimal or absent babbling
  • Echolalia (repeating words or phrases)
  • Pronoun reversals
  • Peculiar voice quality and rhythm
  • Hyperlexia (early reading without comprehension)

Intellectual Disability

Approximately 30% of children with ASD have intellectual disabilities

Irritability

Aggression, self-injurious behaviours, severe temper tantrums

 

Sudden, unexplained mood swings

Atypical Response to Sensory Stimuli

Over- or under-responsiveness to sensory input such as sound or pain

Hyperactivity and Inattention

Common in young children with ASD

Precocious Skills

Exceptional abilities in specific areas such as rote memory, calculation, or music

questions.text: A 5 year old child with known Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) exhibits difficulties in understanding social cues and rarely participates in group activities at school. The teacher reports that he often plays by himself, lining up toys in a particular order, and shows little interest in playing with others. What core symptom of ASD is most likely causing his difficulties in social interaction?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Impaired Theory of Mind

 

Explanation:

The child in this case struggles with social cues and prefers to play alone, which aligns with the social deficits linked to an impaired theory of mind. This inability to understand how others are feeling or what they are thinking makes it challenging for them to engage in typical social interactions, resulting in poor social reciprocity and difficulty in making friends.

 

Core Symptoms of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD)

Deficits in Social Communication and Interaction

Restricted and Repetitive Patterns of Behaviour
  • Reciprocal Social Skills: Difficulty in engaging in back-and-forth social exchanges, may lack typical gestures and eye contact.
  • Attachment Behaviours: Exhibits atypical responses to familiar individuals, showing less emotional expression.
  • Social Cues and Friendships: Difficulty understanding social norms, leading to awkward interactions and trouble making friends.
  • Impaired Theory of Mind: Struggles to recognize or interpret the emotions and intentions of others, hindering empathy and social relationships.
  • Atypical Play Patterns: Engages in repetitive activities rather than imaginative play, and may show rigidity in how toys are used.
  • Ritualistic Behaviours: Tends to perform repetitive actions (e.g., lining up objects) and may form strong attachments to specific items.
  • Resistance to Change: Experiences distress during changes in routine, which can result in anxiety or temper outbursts. (Option B)

 

 

Aetiology of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD):

  • Genetic Factors:
    • Highly heritable with higher prevalence in families and monozygotic twins.
    • Specific genes implicated (e.g., related to serotonin and synaptic plasticity).
  • Environmental Factors:
    • Prenatal and perinatal complications (e.g., advanced parental age, low birth weight).
    • Potential link to hypoxia affecting brain development.
  • Other Factors: Possible immunologic factors, though not fully confirmed.

Delayed Motor Skills (Option C): Although some children with ASD may have motor skill delays, such as difficulties with coordination or fine motor tasks, the child’s main issue in this case is related to social interaction, not motor development.

 

Excessive Aggression (Option D): Aggressive behaviour can occasionally be observed in children with ASD, but it is not a core feature of the disorder. The child described in this scenario shows social withdrawal and a preference for solitary play, which are more indicative of impaired social communication rather than aggression

questions.text: A 10 year old boy with a history of Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder presents with tics that have developed over the past few months. The tics are moderate in severity but interfere with his social interactions and academic performance. Which of the following medications is the most appropriate treatment for managing his ADHD while minimizing the risk of exacerbating the tics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Guanfacine

 

Explanation:

Alpha 2 agonists, e.g., Clonidine, Guanfacine, are FDA approved for the treatment of ADHD in children and adolescents.

  • These are non stimulant medications.
  • Their common adverse effects include:
    • Sedation
    • Headache
    • Fatigue
    • Hypotension
  • Preferred in ADHD and comorbid tic disorder when stimulants increase tics.

Methylphenidate (Option A) is a CNS stimulant medication and is the drug of choice in ADHD.

  • However, It can exacerbate tics and hence be avoided in children with comorbid tic disorders.

 

Amphetamine (Option B) is also a CNS stimulant medication which is the second drug of choice in ADHD.

  • They can exacerbate tics, therefore avoided in such conditions.

 

Modafinil (Option C) is also a CNS stimulant medication used in the treatment of ADHD but it is not FDA approved.

questions.text: A 9 year old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to difficulties in school. After a thorough evaluation, the diagnosis of ADHD is confirmed. The parents are concerned about medication and ask about the first line of treatment. What is the most effective first-line treatment for managing this child?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Stimulant medications

 

Explanation:

Stimulant medications, such as methylphenidate and amphetamines, are considered the first-line treatment for ADHD.

 

Pharmacologic treatment is considered the first line of treatment for ADHD. CNS stimulants are the first choice of agents in that they have the highest efficacy with generally mild tolerable side effects.

Parent training programs (Option B): While parent training helps manage ADHD symptoms, especially behavioural aspects, it is usually part of a broader treatment plan, not the first-line treatment.

 

Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) (Option D): CBT is beneficial for older children and adolescents, helping them develop coping strategies. Psychosocial interventions usually are activities involving paying attention, waiting for their turn, and following instructions. However, it is not the primary treatment in younger children with ADHD.

questions.text: Which of the following is a known contributing factor to the development of ADHD?

choices.text: Familial genetic links, with a heritability of about 75%
Increased activity in the prefrontal cortex

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Familial genetic links, with a heritability of about 75%

 

Explanation:

Genetic factors play a major role in ADHD, with a heritability of about 75%. Genes like DAT1 and DRD4 are linked to the condition. Previously it was described as “minimal brain damage”.

Aetiology of ADHD

Genetic Factors

(Option B)

Neurochemical Factors

Neurophysiological and Neuroanatomical Factors

Developmental Factors

Psychosocial Factors
  • ADHD has a strong genetic link, with a heritability of about 75%.
  • Children with ADHD are more likely to have parents or siblings with the condition, indicating a familial pattern.
  • DAT1 gene and DRD4 gene, are known to be associated with ADHD.
  • ADHD is linked to dopamine dysfunction.
  • The noradrenergic system, which influences attention and alertness, is also believed to play a role.
  • ADHD medications typically increase levels of dopamine and norepinephrine.
  • EEG usually shows theta and beta waves in the frontal brain- indicating inattention and mood swings respectively.
  • Decreased activity in brain areas like the prefrontal cortex, anterior cingulate, and basal ganglia. (Option C)
  • Certain prenatal and perinatal factors, such as premature birth, maternal infections during pregnancy, and low birth weight, may increase the risk of ADHD.
  • Severe abuse, neglect, or maltreatment can worsen or mimic ADHD symptoms.

Dysfunction of the serotonin system (Option A): The dopamine system is indicated in ADHD, not the serotonin. ADHD medications work to increase the levels of Dopamine in the patient

 

Increased activity of norepinephrine (Option D): Norepinephrine activity is usually decreased in patients with ADHD.

questions.text: A 7 year old boy is referred for evaluation due to behavioural concerns. He frequently interrupts others, struggles to stay seated during class, and exhibits difficulty concentrating on tasks. His teacher completes a standardised ADHD rating scale. Which of the following is most useful in confirming an ADHD diagnosis?

choices.text: Symptom duration of at least three months
Symptoms persist after the age of 18
Symptoms impair functioning in multiple settings

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Symptoms impair functioning in multiple settings

 

Explanation:

For an ADHD diagnosis to be confirmed, symptoms must be present in at least two different environments, such as both school and home. This ensures that the behaviour is not limited to one specific context and indicates a broader issue with attention and self-regulation.

 

Symptom duration of at least three months (Option A): The diagnosis of ADHD requires that symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, or impulsivity persist for at least six months, according to standard diagnostic guidelines.

 

Symptoms persist after the age of 18 (Option B): While ADHD can continue into adulthood, the diagnosis is based on symptoms that first emerge before the age of 12. Persisting into adulthood is not a requirement for diagnosis, though it can affect long-term management.

 

Symptoms first appear after age 12 (Option D): According to diagnostic criteria, ADHD symptoms must be observed before age 12. If symptoms emerge after this age, they may be attributable to other factors or conditions.
